website_summaries.verdict: A great choice for experienced tortilla makers and those who don't mind taking the time to master the process. It's a budget-friendly model backed by reliable customer service.
pros: Basic design makes authentic tortillas that are thin and crisp
Cast aluminum construction is durable and easy to clean
Falls on the lower end of the price spectrum
cons: There's a learning curve to using it, which makes it a bit more difficult to produce precise results
The handle has been known to break, but customer service is attentive when issues arise

customer_reviews.title: Get what you pay for
customer_reviews.text: does not press all the way down to a nice flat, thin tortilla. in only a few uses they aluminum at the wedge was scrapping off. I wanted cast iron, should have went with that. I would have to wave anyone off of this, it is cheap and cheap made.
customer_reviews.author: Monte

customer_reviews.title: Fresh tortillas
customer_reviews.text: Living in the back of beyond, there are a lot of things I can't buy locally. Tortilla presses are one of them. I bought this to replace a press lost in a move years ago. It's great. And there's nothing better than fresh tortillas. Just a small learning curve calculating the optimal size dough ball for a large tortilla. (Hint: golf ball size works great)
customer_reviews.author: Helen C. Chapman

customer_reviews.title: I get my best results when I press half way
customer_reviews.text: This little device works perfectly. It makes a small 6-7 inch tortilla. I get my best results when I press half way, then turn the tortilla and press to desired thickness. I want a bigger press now, but this is just right for small corn tortillas.
customer_reviews.author: Elizabeth Flynn

customer_reviews.title: I'm disappointed (cake does not work, aluminum is too weak and deformed in all first use!
customer_reviews.text: I'm disappointed (cake does not work, aluminum is too weak and deformed in all first use!
customer_reviews.author: Evgeniy Kidalov

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Tried, results aren't as expected, I wish I could return.
customer_reviews.author: Farhat Unood

customer_reviews.title: Great Size
customer_reviews.text: My homemade tortillas will be made now to the next level with my new press. Love the size.
customer_reviews.author: PH

customer_reviews.title: It is a piece of junk. To flimsy to ...
customer_reviews.text: It is a piece of junk. To flimsy to flatten a tortilla..After you try to use the press you have to get the rolling pin out.
customer_reviews.author: Robert L. Hill

customer_reviews.title: Okay for some things
customer_reviews.text: I ordered this, as I was learning how to make homemade tortillas. I gave this a 3 star, as it is not heavy enough, to make tortillas (you need a cast iron press, I have learned). With this Aluminum one, after you press the tortilla, you have to put it on a counter and either roll it out flatter or work it out flatter with your hands. However, it can be used to make small pie crusts and other pastries. If you want to make tortillas, I do not recommend this one. If you want one for pastries, this would be perfect.
customer_reviews.author: S. Curley

customer_reviews.title: Don't waste your time or money
customer_reviews.text: I do NOT recommend this product! It only flattens the dough to about a 3 or 4 inch circle. It saves no time as I could easily do that with my hand and still have to roll it out. Go with a heavier duty tortilla press, not aluminum.
customer_reviews.author: S Narra

customer_reviews.title: Very nice press for the money!
customer_reviews.text: Started using this to make my own gluten free tortillas. I still use my rolling pin to thin them, but this is a great press.
customer_reviews.author: Mary A Walker

customer_reviews.title: This makes great tortillas. Make sure your tortilla mix has just ...
customer_reviews.text: This makes great tortillas. Make sure your tortilla mix has just enough water and you shouldn't have to put too much force on the handle to flatten the tortilla.
customer_reviews.author: James

customer_reviews.title: but I would have liked it to be a little
customer_reviews.text: It is OK, but I would have liked it to be a little heavier
customer_reviews.author: Liz from Idaho

customer_reviews.title: they came out perfect.
customer_reviews.text: I used this for making the top crust for individual pot pies, they came out perfect.
customer_reviews.author: Aaron Flores

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Love, made a batch of homemade tortillas the first night
customer_reviews.author: Tinkerbell

customer_reviews.title: DO NOT WASTE YOUR
customer_reviews.text: First time I used the tortilla press the handle snapped right off. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY
customer_reviews.author: Jay Gralnick

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Very thick tortillas. I still have to roll them out
customer_reviews.author: michelle avecillas

customer_reviews.title: Do not buy
customer_reviews.text: This product is of no use it does nothing to make tortillas it is not 8 inch is more like 4 inch pita maker
customer_reviews.author: Ronald J. Hall

customer_reviews.title: light weight and much gap inbetween
customer_reviews.text: not good for thin tortilla. may be good for 3-4 inch thick tortilla
customer_reviews.author: Krish

customer_reviews.title: Complete turd. The aluminum is too thin and flexible ...
customer_reviews.text: Complete turd. The aluminum is too thin and flexible. After the first tortilla is made the 2 mating surfaced on this thing no longer touch in the center, they are permanently warped. How this thing made it to market I'll never know.
customer_reviews.author: Scott

customer_reviews.title: Complete waste of money
customer_reviews.text: Complete waste of money. I only used this press on two occasions before the handle completely snapped off. The press also doesn't produce even, thin tortillas. Don't bother with aluminum.
customer_reviews.author: Amy E. Diaz

customer_reviews.title: Low Quality Product
customer_reviews.text: Garbage. Made very cheaply and has no 'leverage' like it claims. You're literally better off rolling out your own tortillas with a rolling pin.
customer_reviews.author: TheWerbinator

customer_reviews.title: Satisfied with Cast Aluminum Tortilla Press
customer_reviews.text: We bought the silver tortilla press through Amazon about a year ago. We've only used it a few times, but it's working fine. I was tempted to buy a more traditional-looking one (since this one looks and feels a bit like plastic), but I'm glad we found a tortilla press in a lower price-range. I didn't like that we had to use plastic sheets to prevent sticking, but I've heard that it's normal even with traditional-looking tortilla presses. We wash and re-use the plastic, and I guess it's better than having to wash the entire tortilla press. It is very lightweight, so I was a bit worried about the handle breaking off, but it feels sturdy when we use it.
customer_reviews.author: Carmen Ruel

customer_reviews.title: Too Flimsy...Invest In Cast Iron Instead
customer_reviews.text: This was my first tortilla press purchase. I used it only once and when I was pressing the dough, the metal piece that holds the hinge under the handle was bending and torquing. I'm reasonably sure this would eventually snap or crack with very little effort. Aluminum is too soft to be used for a tool that depends on the use of force or torque, IMO. The tortillas I pressed with this gadget were also uneven and too thick. I returned it for a refund & bought a cast iron model instead.
customer_reviews.author: shrinking footprint

product_meta.title: IMUSA USA MEXI-86009M Cast Aluminum Tortilla & Roti Press 8-Inch, Silver
product_meta.description: Imusa aluminum tortilla press is a best seller in the U.S. The traditional and durable design allows for perfectly pressed homemade tortillas, with just the right thickness and round shape. The tortilla press is an essential tool in any Mexican kitchen. Tortillas have been used for many centuries, particularly in Mexico and more recently in the United States. The tortilla is consumed all year round, and are most commonly prepared with meat to make dishes such as tacos, burritos, and enchiladas. Easy to use – just insert your dough or ‘masa’ and with one press, a fresh tortilla. Impress your guests with homemade tortillas at your next Mexican-themed dinner!
feature_bullets: Traditional Style Press With Excellent Leverage
Creates Flat Homemade Tortillas and Roti with just the Right Thickness and Round Shape
Ideal for Both Corn and Flour Tortillas and Roti
